text: yeah hi everyone Anthony Fantana here
the Internet's busiest me sick nerd and
it's time for a review of the new blood
orange album Cupid deluxe blood orange
is the musical project of singer
songwriter and multi-instrumentalist
Devante Hines who you might know for his
other recordings under the name like
speed champion or even earlier as a part
of the band test icicles
of course these projects were in
different musical styles but this blood
orange project of his this is his
sophomore album under this name and this
project is one that he uses to not play
singer-songwriter music or chamber pop
or indie rock or pop or dance punk
genres that Devante has played in his
earlier career but this is all about
synth pop synth funk contemporary R&B
especially these sounds as they were
being portrayed in the eighties this guy
tends to where his influences on his
sleeve the likes of Michael Jackson
Billy ocean Lionel Richie and Prince
I'll show up in his tunes in some way
shape or form and he grabs all these
influences and he portrays them in a way
that's really smooth but also very
inoffensive and not that catchy or
memorable it's like he's grabbing all of
the nostalgic Kitsch but just taking out
the personality with the vocals and the
very sensual grooves on this album
it's like blood oranges shooting for
sweet and sexy but instead he delivers
an album that goes down like a warm flat
glass of Mountain Dew there is a lot of
revivalism going on right now but
there's nothing on this record that says
to me that blood orange is great
bringing these sounds back with the
ambition of like Daft Punk's latest
record or the eccentricity of destroyers
latest record or the conceptual ideas of
a Janelle Monae across the 11 tracks
here there are some decent dance grooves
being dished out but that is where the
strong points of this album start and
end because truthfully the songs here
are so uneventful that it really becomes
difficult not to tune
after halfway in to any of them
especially since blood orange doesn't
really progress a lot of these songs
compositionally as they continue not
only that but the lyrics and the vocals
for every track on this thing just sound
like hilarious mimicry I'm singin ACK
this these songs have nothing but weak
falsettos and breathy vibrato 'he's on
top of weak falsettos and breathy
vibrato 'he's sometimes sometimes it's
tolerable like on the opening track and
the song you're not good enough but even
these songs sound like they were made
with the intent to just merely be
background music for whatever store you
go to at the mall to buy overpriced
clothing I actually think the first
interesting moment on this entire LP
occurs on the song uncle ace and believe
me it is not due to the cheesy sax solo
in the middle of this thing and the
really melodramatic spoken word which is
not attractive at all actually I would
call these two things low points on this
record right up there with hearing David
long strength of the Dirty Projectors
sing in this similarly sexy way on the
song no right thing which believe me is
not sexy or entertaining at all it's
like this entire record is just devoted
to bringing back this singing style that
was hot in the 80s and just redoing it
in the most unflattering way possible
really the only interesting part of this
whole song uncle ace are these woodwinds
and horns toward the back end that are
arranged in a way where it sounds like
it's part of an epic Philip Glass piece
it really sounds like Devante is
borrowing straight from that Philip
Glass playbook and as much of a ripoff
as it sounds like it kind of makes me
wonder if he can put together musical
pieces like this why is he hanging
around in the doldrums of offensively
simple synth funk and songs that rehash
the same instrumental ideas over and
over and over throughout the track to
the point where the song gets stale like
on the line and time will tell the
record can't even manage to pull
together a good vocal feature from
singers who are proven to be good
singers like Caroline pull a check of
chairlift or the rapper despot who raps
for the majority of one single track on
here while I do think he is a good
lyricist the very hard nails tone of his
voice just does not
fit on this record at all it really
ruins what little flow this LP has going
for it already the UK based rapper
sceptic ahooo is featured toward the
back end of this LP the tone of his
voice and just the subtlety of his
delivery is much more fitting for what
goes on here instrumentally but still I
don't really see how his success or him
starting to make it in the music
industry which is what he raps about in
this song is really relevant to the
theme of this record out of all of his
vocal features Hines gives the most
airtime to Samantha herb annie of the
band friends who was easily the least
interesting vocalist
of everyone who was invited onto this
thing not only was the full-length from
her main band friends really
underwhelming but the first few lines
she sings on the song it is what it is
just sound incredibly awkward and and
very amateurish that and the song always
let you down and it's like there's no
effort to remedy this at all
instrumentally these songs feel off at
times to either rhythm guitars slightly
out of place or the synth solo on the
song you're not good enough which is
just really really shoddy and boring or
the slap bass line on the song always
let you down and swing and across the
cell P instrumentally I feel like
Devante runs out of ideas too like the
track always let you down feels like a
little bit of a rehash of the first song
on here not to mention that it sounds a
lot like a track off of glasses first
album as well again the only thing I
really liked about this LP is that I
thought that some of the grooves were
pretty good but they're never structured
into an interesting song the vocal
melodies and the lyrics and the refrains
and choruses are never really that
memorable neither is the singing that
great and really that is maybe the
biggest kicker on this entire thing if
the singing was fantastic then maybe the
incredibly bland songs and instrumentals
wouldn't be that big of a deal but they
really are simply because there's
nothing else to really pay attention to
for me Cupid deluxe is a shining example
of the darker side of modern music's
current addiction to nostalgia because I
feel like we're merely gravitating
toward this record because of this lost
essence that it's captured versus what's
actually going on here musically
compositionally or vocally sitting
through this record is like having
someone try to seduce you
for 50 minutes straight after you've
already told them no ten times because I
do not find anything sexy moody
emotional or attractive about what goes
on here honestly I'm really feeling a
light decent too on this thing
transition if you give it to Sophia
listen what did you think of it did you
love it
hate it why what do you think I should
review next and that's it Anthony
Fantino blood orange forever
